snippet: The rules the Federal Reserve approved this week are intended to ensure that banks have enough ready liquidity to survive a crisis of 30 days, which proved not to be the case in the 2008 crisis.
abstract: Floyd Norris High & Low Finance column examines new rules approved by Federal Reserve that are intended to ensure banks have enough liquidity to survive a crisis of 30 days; argues that rules have become far tougher and that banks now enjoy less discretion in defining their assets, but notes that questions remain about whether changes are sufficient to prevent a repeat of the 2008 meltdown.
lead_paragraph: The rules the Federal Reserve approved this week are intended to ensure that banks have enough ready liquidity to survive a crisis of 30 days, which proved not to be the case in the 2008 crisis.

headline.print_headline: Liquidity for Banks, This Time Defined
headline.seo: Fed Rules Tighten What Counts as an Asset
headline.main: Liquidity for Banks, This Time Defined
